awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Hexacoordinate pincer complexes for organic electronic devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to develop materials for organic electronic devices.  Relevant applications include organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs), organic photovoltaic cells (OPVs), large panel displays, and implantable/wearable biotech devices. The switch to organic electronics offers flexible, lighter, cheaper, and more sustainable devices.  The materials being developed offer customized charge transport properties optimized for the various needs of the electronics industry sectors.  The materials are compatible with current material processing techniques and are ready for rapid integration into existing device manufacturing streams.  These materials could enhance the device efficiency, leading to devices that can last longer before needing to be recharged, as well as device lifetime.         

This I-Corps project is based on the hexacoordinate Si(pincer)2 platform, uniquely suited for synthetic tailoring to meet the demand for low-cost materials with improved charge mobility in the organic electronics industry.  The push-pull, charge transport nature of the pincer ligands allow for selective tuning of the material's HOMO or LUMO levels,  accurately predicted through molecular modeling.  The molecular geometry of the Si(pincer)2 complexes enhances solid state packing efficiency to facilitate charge transport, while also ensuring negligible dipole moments and higher vapor pressure for thermal evaporation.  The hexacoordinate silicon center also enforces planarity of the dianionic pincer ligands. The materials are compatible with current thermal evaporation techniques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHARLOTTE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs) are found in televisions, displays, cell phones and many other devices. The OLED contains a stack of different organic materials to bring electrons in and out of the device and convert the electricity to light. One of the essential layers is the electron transport layer which transfers electrons from the cathode to the active region where emission occurs. Researchers at UNC Charlotte are developing electron transport layer materials based on hexacoordinate silicon complexes to lower the cost of OLED fabrication while also improving the device efficiency and lifetime.     

A team consisting of the CEO of Light and Charge Solutions (L&CS), representatives of UNC Charlotte, and an industrial mentor participated in the national NSF I-Corps program (Jan.-Feb., 2020 - Winter Cohort 1, Dallas TX) to explore commercialization of hexacoordinate silicon pincer complexes for organic electronic applications. A round of customer discovery focused on the challenges or problems related to current electron transport materials used by the domestic OLED industry. We interviewed 126 engineers and executives from throughout the organic light emitting diode (OLED) industry, including manufacturers of OLED TVs, flexible displays, portable phones, implantable biotech, and large-area lighting. All 126 interviews were conducted in person by one or more members of team. 

Strong product/market fit was identified between the needs of the OLED industry and the value provided by the hexacoorinate silicon pincer technology.L&CS and UNC Charlotte have filed for patents in US, Korea, China, EU, and Japan. Prototype materials have been distributed to potential customers.

Broader Impacts:

Results from the customer discovery were used to support a successgul STTR grant for L&CS and UNCC, NSF Award #2105931 - STTR Phase I: Printable electron transport layers (PrETLs) for organic electronics. It is anticiapted that printable electron transport layers will expidite the transition to printable electronics - a tranisiton that will benefit society by significantly lowering the cost of electronic and photovoltaic devices. 

The I-Corps program and customer discovery process provided entrepreneurial training and an introduction to lean start-up philisophy for the members of the L&CS team including the two gradaute student participants. Margaret Kocherga (a graudate student who led the team as the entrepreneurial lead) and her company L&CS were subsequently selected for the Argonne Chain Reaction Innovation entrepreneurial development program to commercialize the technology, along with non-diluting salary support and R&D funding.

 


Last Modified: 05/11/2022
Modified by: Thomas A Schmedake
